questions.question: take off
questions.answer: To remove something or to leave the ground (airplane).
questions.example: The plane will take off at 3 PM.
choices: To remove something or to leave the ground (airplane).

questions.question: take out
questions.answer: To remove something or to go on a date.
questions.example: I need to take out the trash.
choices: To remove something or to go on a date.

questions.question: take in
questions.answer: To absorb or understand something.
questions.example: It was hard to take in all the information at once.

questions.question: take over
questions.answer: To assume control or responsibility.
questions.example: She will take over the project next week.

questions.question: take up
questions.answer: To begin a new activity or occupy space.
questions.example: I want to take up painting as a hobby.
choices: To begin a new activity or occupy space.

questions.question: take back
questions.answer: To return something or retract a statement.
questions.example: I need to take back the book I borrowed.
choices: To return something or retract a statement.

questions.question: take apart
questions.answer: To disassemble something.
questions.example: He took apart the clock to fix it.

questions.question: take down
questions.answer: To remove or write something down.
questions.example: Please take down the notes from the meeting.
choices: To remove or write something down.

questions.question: take on
questions.answer: To accept a challenge or responsibility.
questions.example: She decided to take on the new project.
choices: To accept a challenge or responsibility.
To remove or write something down.

questions.question: take off
questions.answer: To become successful or popular.
questions.example: Her career took off after the first album.
choices: To remove or write something down.

questions.question: take after
questions.answer: To resemble a family member.
questions.example: She takes after her mother in looks.

questions.question: take aside
questions.answer: To separate someone from a group to talk privately.
questions.example: He took me aside to discuss the plan.
choices: To separate someone from a group to talk privately.

questions.question: take away
questions.answer: To remove something from a place.
questions.example: Please take away the dishes from the table.
choices: To remove something from a place.

questions.question: take back
questions.answer: To retract a statement or opinion.
questions.example: I take back what I said about him.
choices: To retract a statement or opinion.

questions.question: take down
questions.answer: To write down or record.
questions.example: Can you take down my number?

questions.question: take in
questions.answer: To fully understand or comprehend.
questions.example: It was a lot of information to take in.

questions.question: take off
questions.answer: To remove something, especially clothing.
questions.example: Please take off your shoes before entering.

questions.question: take out
questions.answer: To remove something from a place.
questions.example: I will take out the garbage.
choices: To remove something from a place.

questions.question: take over
questions.answer: To gain control of something.
questions.example: The company was taken over by a larger firm.

questions.question: take up
questions.answer: To start a new hobby or activity.
questions.example: I have decided to take up jogging.
choices: To start a new hobby or activity.

questions.question: take after
questions.answer: To resemble someone in appearance or character.
questions.example: He takes after his father.
choices: To resemble someone in appearance or character.

questions.question: take aside
questions.answer: To talk to someone privately.
questions.example: Can you take me aside for a moment?

questions.question: take away
questions.answer: To remove something to another place.
questions.example: They took away my doubts after the explanation.
choices: To remove something to another place.

questions.question: take back
questions.answer: To return to a previous state or condition.
questions.example: The software update took back some features.
choices: To return to a previous state or condition.

questions.question: take down
questions.answer: To remove something from a high place.
questions.example: Please take down the flag.
choices: To remove something from a high place.

questions.question: take in
questions.answer: To absorb information or experiences.
questions.example: She takes in everything he says.

questions.question: take off
questions.answer: To leave the ground and begin to fly.
questions.example: The bird will take off at dawn.
choices: To leave the ground and begin to fly.

questions.question: take out
questions.answer: To remove something from its place.
questions.example: I will take out the old batteries.
choices: To remove something from its place.

questions.question: take over
questions.answer: To control something completely.
questions.example: He will take over the family business.

questions.question: take up
questions.answer: To occupy space or time.
questions.example: This desk takes up too much space.

questions.question: take after
questions.answer: To look or behave like an older relative.
questions.example: She takes after her grandmother.
choices: To look or behave like an older relative.

questions.question: take aside
questions.answer: To remove from consideration or discussion.
questions.example: Let's take that issue aside for now.
choices: To remove from consideration or discussion.

questions.question: take away
questions.answer: To subtract or remove a part from the whole.
questions.example: If you take away 10 from 50, you get 40.
choices: To subtract or remove a part from the whole.

questions.question: take back
questions.answer: To withdraw a statement or offer.
questions.example: I take back my words; I was wrong.
choices: To withdraw a statement or offer.

questions.question: take down
questions.answer: To reduce in size or importance.
questions.example: The CEO had to take down his expectations.
choices: To reduce in size or importance.

questions.question: take in
questions.answer: To include or contain.
questions.example: The bill does not take in the service charge.

questions.question: take off
questions.answer: To remove someone from a job or position.
questions.example: The manager had to take off an employee for misconduct.
choices: To remove someone from a job or position.

questions.question: take out
questions.answer: To kill or destroy.
questions.example: The sniper was ordered to take out the target.

questions.question: take over
questions.answer: To take control of a situation.
questions.example: He will take over the negotiations.
choices: To take control of a situation.

questions.question: take up
questions.answer: To resume after an interruption.
questions.example: Let's take up where we left off.

questions.question: take after
questions.answer: To follow or pursue.
questions.example: The dog will take after the cat.

questions.question: take aside
questions.answer: To reserve or set apart for a particular purpose.
questions.example: I will take aside some money for your gift.
choices: To reserve or set apart for a particular purpose.

questions.question: take away
questions.answer: To carry something away.
questions.example: The police took away the evidence.

questions.question: take back
questions.answer: To regain possession of something.
questions.example: He managed to take back his stolen bike.

questions.question: take down
questions.answer: To dismantle or destroy.
questions.example: They had to take down the old building.

questions.question: take in
questions.answer: To take something into one's possession.
questions.example: The police took in the suspect for questioning.
choices: To take something into one's possession.

questions.question: take off
questions.answer: To become airborne.
questions.example: The helicopter will take off from the roof.

questions.question: take out
questions.answer: To remove someone from a dangerous situation.
questions.example: The hero took out the villain.
choices: To remove someone from a dangerous situation.

questions.question: take over
questions.answer: To take control of someone else's responsibilities.
questions.example: I will take over your duties while you're away.
choices: To take control of someone else's responsibilities.

questions.question: take up
questions.answer: To fill a particular amount of space or time.
questions.example: This project will take up most of my time.
choices: To fill a particular amount of space or time.

questions.question: take after
questions.answer: To resemble or be similar to.
questions.example: You take after your mother.
choices: To resemble or be similar to.

questions.question: take aside
questions.answer: To separate from the group for a specific purpose.
questions.example: He was taken aside for a private conversation.
choices: To separate from the group for a specific purpose.

questions.question: take away
questions.answer: To remove something from a particular place.
questions.example: Please take away these old newspapers.
choices: To remove something from a particular place.

questions.question: take back
questions.answer: To retract or withdraw a previous statement.
questions.example: I take back my criticism; it was unwarranted.
choices: To retract or withdraw a previous statement.

questions.question: take down
questions.answer: To remove from a higher to a lower position.
questions.example: Can you take down that picture?
choices: To remove from a higher to a lower position.

questions.question: take in
questions.answer: To absorb or assimilate information.
questions.example: He couldn't take in all the details.

questions.question: take off
questions.answer: To remove something quickly.
questions.example: He took off running when he saw the dog.

questions.question: take out
questions.answer: To remove someone from a group, often secretly.
questions.example: The spy was to take out the target discreetly.
choices: To remove someone from a group, often secretly.

questions.question: take over
questions.answer: To assume control, often without the original owner's consent.
questions.example: The rebels managed to take over the city.
choices: To assume control, often without the original owner's consent.

questions.question: take up
questions.answer: To start doing a new activity or hobby.
questions.example: I think I will take up yoga.
choices: To start doing a new activity or hobby.

questions.question: take after
questions.answer: To behave or look like an older relative.
questions.example: He takes after his uncle.
choices: To behave or look like an older relative.

questions.question: take aside
questions.answer: To talk to someone privately about something important.
questions.example: I need to take you aside to discuss your performance.
choices: To talk to someone privately about something important.

questions.question: take away
questions.answer: To remove something from someone's possession.
questions.example: The teacher had to take away the student's phone.
choices: To remove something from someone's possession.

questions.question: take back
questions.answer: To return to a previous place or condition.
questions.example: He had to take back his words after realizing the truth.
choices: To return to a previous place or condition.

questions.question: take down
questions.answer: To remove something from a vertical position.
questions.example: Please take down the curtains.
choices: To remove something from a vertical position.

questions.question: take in
questions.answer: To fully understand or grasp an idea.
questions.example: It took a while to take in the new policy changes.
choices: To fully understand or grasp an idea.

questions.question: take off
questions.answer: To remove something that is worn.
questions.example: He took off his hat indoors.
choices: To remove something that is worn.

questions.question: take out
questions.answer: To remove someone from a place, often with force.
questions.example: The bouncer had to take out the troublemaker.
choices: To remove someone from a place, often with force.

questions.question: take over
questions.answer: To take control of something, often suddenly.
questions.example: The manager will take over the project from here.
choices: To take control of something, often suddenly.
